titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: 1. VI. My brotherswife, went this morning to Haverhill to see her father who lies dangerously ill— My Son George went to Boston, and entered Mr Webster’s Office as a Student at Law; where he is to read one year in addition to the two that he has passed with me since he was graduated at Cambridge— Received an invitation from Governor and Mrs Eustis to accompany them to-morrow Evening to the Theatre, which I declined. It is after a military review— I was employed in drawing up powers to my Son George, as my Agent for managing my Affairs— Then went with Mrs Adams and visited at Mrs Quincy’s— Her daughter Susan gave me a drawing of Mount Wollaston made by her— In the afternoon I rode with my father to Jedediah Adams’s to return to him the original authenticated copy of my great grandfather Joseph Adams’s Will; but Jedidiah let him have it, for ten dollars, and he gave it to me— He asked Jedidiah, if he had any more old family papers— He said he had, and would bring and shew them to us tomorrow Evening. We then went to Mr Wales’s, the Braintree Town Clerk— He was not at home, but I again examined his Town records for about an hour. My father bespoke an entire copy of them. On returning we stopped at Mr Marstons and took up Susan Clarke, and my brothers two Sons John Quincy, and Joseph Harrod.

2. V:30. Day of the great Review at Boston— My brother went, and took with him his two Sons Isaac Hull and John Quincy— Came back in the Evening, having left the latter in Boston— I rode with my father to visit Ebenezer and Josiah Adams, sons of Ebenezer Adams who was first Cousin to my father both in the male and female line— We returned home through my Land, the old patrimonial Estate; and by the houses where my father, and myself were born— After dinner I was much occupied in writing preparatory to our departure— A Captain Austin with Sailing Master Hutson came out from Boston, and brought despatches from J. B. Prevost at Lima, and from Condy Raguet, Consul at Rio de Janeiro— Mr Marston was here this Evening— And Jedidiah Adams, who brought all the old family records in his possession— They were chiefly deeds and Commissions of his father, Peter Adams, Son of Peter, and Grandson of Joseph Adams junr. my father’s Grandfather—but among them was a parchment copy of the Will of the first Henry Adams who died in 1646. The stock from whom the whole family are descended— There is also an Inventory of all his Estate, real and personal, apprized at 75 pounds 13 shillings and eight pence— In this Will, mention is made of five Sons and one daughter— But Henry Adams had three other Sons— In the next Generation, Joseph Adams, Senior, had six Sons and six daughters; and his Son Joseph Adams junr. had two daughters by his first wife Mary Chapin, and five Sons and three daughters by his second wife Hannah Bass— One of these was my fathers father—John Adams— From his time the family has been less prolific.

3. V:15. I came to no Settlement with my brother—for I found it impracticable— I made copies of the Will and Inventory of the first Henry Adams, and have thus obtained as I apprehend all the information now to be had of my paternal ancestors— Had their lives been recorded as minutely as my own has been in the volumes of my diary, perhaps I should not have been tempted to look into them— The absence of information stimulates curiosity which can never be gratified— Laborious, frugal, and honest lives, may be safely ascribed to them all— May nothing worse ever be said of mine, or of those of my Children— We took leave of my aged and venerable father and came into Boston. Stopp’d on the way at Governor Eustis’s, and bade Adieu to him. He said to me, that he would wish to serve me by anything in his power, for he knew that there were deep intrigues in operation against
me— I thanked him for his friendly disposition, and told him if I should have occasion for his friendship, I would write to him— If he had told me what were the intrigues against me, known to him, it would have been a proof of friendship instead of a profession; but I asked no questions— We came to Dr Welsh’s house, where my Son George has a chamber and boards— I called with him at Mr Cruft’s. He settled his Accounts with me; and transferred the papers in his hands relating to my concerns to George— I dined with a party of friends at Mr William Sturgis’s— In the Evening I called and visited Mr William Gray whom I found in deep affliction— Mrs Gray died last weeks after an illness of a few days. I also called at Mr James H. Foster’s, where I found my brothers Son John Quincy, and at Mr Joseph Hall’s of whom I took leave— Engaged a seat for the morning in the Barry Stage, and came to pass the Night at Dr Welsh’s— Our arrangement is, that I go to Princeton, to pass the Sunday with Mr Boylston— Then go across the Country to take the Steam-boat from Providence on Tuesday Evening— Mrs Adams, and our Son John, return to-morrow to Quincy— And proceed thence on Monday in our own Carriage to meet me on Tuesday at Providence. I wrote this morning some lines addressed to my Son Charles.

4. V:15— Made various arrangements this morning with my Son George, and left him to commence his career in the world— The Stage called for me, about seven O’Clock in the Morning, at Dr Welsh’s, and I took my departure from Boston— We came through Cambridge, Watertown, Waltham and Stow, where a Miss Whitman who was a passenger with us alighted— One of the Passengers was named Greenwood; another Robinson, and we took up on the road a Mr Brown, and old man of 67 with much self-conceit of wit, who got into the Stage, merely to take a ride— We dined at Bolton, and about five in the afternoon arrived at Mr Boylston’s at Princeton, where I landed— Found Mr Brooks there— Mr J. B. Davis soon came in, and afterwards Mr Boylston’s son; with Moses Gill, from Worcester. The Supreme Court of the State have been this week in Session there, and some suit relating to Gill’s subsistance is still pending— Gill lives, and fattens upon Charity, and has a family of children. My fellow passengers in the Stage were all unknown to me— I was at first so to them; but became an object of curiosity to some of them, and partly of surprize, till at last one of them asked me, if my name was John Quincy Adams?—but this was an ex-yankee from Natchez— I was racking my wits the whole day, in making dull verses.

5. V: The day was dreary—with Rain— We rode to the Meeting—Morn and afternoon. The house was very thin— Heard Mr Clark, the Clergyman of the place—from Romans 2.6.7.8.9. “Who will render to every man according to his deeds:—to them who by patient continuance in well doing seek for glory and honour and immortality, eternal life:—But unto them that are contentious and do not obey the truth, but obey unrighteousness, indignation and wrath,—Tribulation and anguish upon every soul of man that doeth evil, of the Jew first, and also of the Gentile.” An exposition of the retributive justice of God, proportioned to the good or evil deeds of man— After the morning service the Banns were published of a couple intending marriage— Mr Boylston’s son, and his wife were with us at dinner— We visited towards Evening the Farm-house and the Cattle. Mr Clarke, and Mr Davis spent the Evening with us— Mr Boylston this morning shewed me the Bond, to which his signature was obtained by fraud; and which a Jury, after trial in the Supreme Court, found on that account to be not his deed— It involved his whole fortune, and if it had been found valid by the Jury, would have utterly ruined him. He told me the story of it, and of the years of anguish and terror which he endured while it was suspended over his head— H. G. Otis who was Counsel to Boylston, at the time when the Bond was signed is deeply implicated in this transaction— The Bond is in his hand writing, and Boylston is deeply convinced that Otis was privy to the fraud, by which the signature was obtained— It was done, by slipping it in, among several other papers to be executed, and was signed by him among the rest, without being aware of what it contained— I asked
how it happened, and he said he had called, I think at Otis’s Office, to sign two or three Deeds prepared by Otis; but supposing he knew their Contents entirely; being much hurried, and having met with an accident of dislocating his arm shortly before, he had signed the papers without reading them critically over, and without a conception of the engagement which it afterwards appeared had been smuggled into it, that he would indemnify the creditors of the late Moses Gill, for all his debts— He was thunderstruck, when years afterwards an action was brought against him upon this bond; and Otis had no better advice to give him, than to shrink from the full investigation of the subject, and withdraw from the Commonwealth— His opinion of Otis’s motives throughout this affair, is darker than he ventures to express— The whole subject is unaccountable to me, upon any principle which it is pleasing to contemplate— Mr Boylston also gave me a pamphlet of Dr Zabdiel Boylston’s, upon inoculation for the Small-pox, published in 1724.

6. V: There is a Stage that goes three times a week from Worcester to Providence, in which it was my intention to have travelled, but as it left Worcester at six this morning, I must have gone there last Evening to have been in time for it— Mr Boylston therefore determined to send his son John with me in a Horse-Chaise to Providence— About 8 this morning we left his house at Princeton, and rode 14 Miles to Worcester— Stopp’d at Thomas’s, formerly Sykes’s Hotel— Mr Lincoln the Lieutenant Governor called upon me there, and invited me to his house; but I was obliged to proceed— The Supreme Court is still in Session this week; and there is to be a Cattle-shew, and a Military Review, at which the Governor will attend— I had received an invitation from Mr Lincoln to dine with him on the day of the Cattle-shew, which I was obliged to decline— We came from Worcester 8 Miles to Grafton, where we dined at Wood’s, on the Hill opposite the Meeting house— At this distance there is a distinct view of Wachusett-Hill; which to the eye seems scarcely 7 miles distant, though really at least 20— After dinner we came 10 Miles to Mendon—Childs’s, and then 7 to Curtis’s, Bellingham, where we arrived at the dusk of Evening, and stop to lodge this Night— There was a noisy company of young men at the house, for which the Landlady apologized. The day had been fair and cool, and the Evening was autumnal-frosty, with the first sight of the new-moon— The Country through which we travelled from Worcester was new to me, and bore every where the appearance of industry ease and comfort. Before 9 O’Clock I retired to bed.

7. V. We left Bellingham, after breakfasting, and at 7 O’Clock. 4 Miles to Cumberland the first town in the State of Rhode-Island, then 8 to Pawtucket; where we stop’d, and Mr Boylston, for fear of over straining his horse, left him there, to take him on his return, and took another; which brought us 5 Miles to Providence— Arrived there at 11. in the Morning. We stopp’d at Horton’s Tavern; heretofore Chapotin’s; but he is dead— My wife and my Son John were already there: with Mrs Guista, and Mary Ann Mason, a young woman who is going with us as waiting maid, to Mrs Adams— Walked round the town with Mr Boylston, and to the Steam-Boat Fulton, in which I bespoke our passage— At Noon Mr Boylston took his departure to return home. We dined at Providence, and several visitors called upon me in the course of the day. President Messer of the University; and Mr Cozzens— Messrs.Ives, Richmond, and Nicholas Brown— Just before Sunset we came on board the Boat, with numerous other passengers— Our Coachman Joseph Abbot, with the Carriage, and Thomas Allen, a young man, who goes to live with us a waiting man, left Providence to proceed by Land to New-York— Mr Pitman the District Attorney came on board in the Evening, and I took an hour’s walk with him on shore— He told me the state of Public opinion here, federal, and
Republican; with Mr Crawford’s electioneering movements, here and at Newport; with Elisha B. Potter and with William Hunter—and the displacement and replacement of the Officers of the customs, through his agency— At 9 O’Clock this Evening the Steam Boat Fulton, Captain Comstock left the wharf at Providence, and I very soon afterwards retired to bed— The Boat being crowded to excess with Passengers; most of them to me unknown.

8. V:30. The Boat reached Newport about Midnight, and stopp’d two hours, taking onboard a large recruit of Passengers— On turning the cape at Point-Judith, the heavy motion of the boat awakened me, and when I rose this morning we were opposite to the Watch-Hill Light-House— We passed through Fisher’s Island Sound, and had a very pleasant day of prosperous Navigation, with about 150 Passengers; among whom 60. Ladies. Dr Rogers of Philadelphia, a Baptist Clergyman, and his two daughters, with a Miss Wood. Families of Rotches, Girard’s, Coffin’s, Littlefields, Appleton’s, a Mr Dall, and many other’s—the names of three fourths of whom were unknown— The weather was fine; and the decks crowded the whole day— Desultory Conversations, with Dr. Rogers, with Mr Rotch of New-Bedford, and with an old inhabitant of Boston, Mr Dall— John had bought at Providence the 6th. 7th. and 8th. Cantos of Lord Byrons Don Juan, just published, and I read them in the course of the day— The thought struck me of filling up the leisure of my journey by composing a few Stanza’s in the same measure— I found it not very difficult; but it kept my mind continually upon the stretch— About 9 in the Evening the Boat came to Anchor before Hell-gate; the Captain declining to venture through that passage in the Night.

9. V. At daylight the Boat got again under weigh, and about 6 in the Morning we landed at New-York, and immediately proceeded to the City-Hotel. We found there Mr Thomas B. Johnson, Mrs Adams’s brother, who came on, a few days since, from Newport, and intends returning shortly to New-Orleans. Mrs Adams, finding herself excessively fatigued, having passed two Nights successively in the stifling crowd of the Steam-boat Cabins, with sixty women, and ten or fifteen children, is quite unwell, and concluded to stay this day and Night at New-York, and to proceed to-morrow to Bordentown, where she is to pass a few days at Mr Hopkinson’s— Our Son John, and Mrs Giusta remain with her— Mr Heman Allen, the appointed Minister to Chili called upon me after breakfast. Commodore Hull with Mrs Hull and her sister Miss Hart also visited us— A Mr Charles J. Johnson, and two Messrs. Cotheals’ called upon me, on business to which I had not time to attend— At 11. O’Clock I embarked in the Union-Line Steamboat; landed about 4 in the afternoon at Brunswick, and then proceeded in the Stage, through Princeton to Trenton. We arrived there between 9 and 10 in the Evening, and found a supper prepared, after which I had a small bed chamber to myself. Dr Rogers, and Mr. Appleton with their families, continue to be my fellow-travellers, and there are many others. Mary Ann Mason goes with me.

10. IV:30. Before daylight, and after rising, I found it was not time for going to the Boat. I returned to my chamber, and was writing several Stanzas composed yesterday in the Steam-boats and Stages, till all the company went off, and a waiter knocking at my door, advised me that I should be too late— I hastened immediately to the Boat which left the wharf about five; after stopping to land and take in passengers at Burlington and Bristol, we reached Philadelphia at ten. I called at the Bank of the United States Bank, where I met General Cadwaladar, and saw the President of the Bank, Nicholas Biddle. He went with me to Mr Hopkinson’s, whom we found at home, with all his family— Mary Hellen was also there; having passed some weeks, since our absence from Washington with them— I met in the Street Mr S. Ewing, and called at his house— He and Mr Biddle accompanied me to the Steam-boat for Newcastle, which left the Market-Street wharf
at Noon— As I passed into the Boat, Mr Southard, the Secretary of the Navy passed out of it, just from Washington, and going on a visit to his family at Trenton— We reached Newcastle at 6. P.M. and travelled seven Stages full, to Frenchtown— Of this company, Mr Appleton and his family were the only persons who had been with us all the way from Providence. The immense increase of travelling, one of the remarkable consequences of the invention of Steam-Boats— At 10 P.M. embarked in the Steam-Boat Constitution at Frenchtown, and immediately departed— Boat crowded with Passengers. Drew Lots for a bed— Birth N. 22.

11. IV:30— Washington— We landed about five O’Clock this Morning at Baltimore; and on going up to the Stage-Office I found the Stage at the door, ready to depart, and immediately took seats in it. The Stage was full; but of entire Strangers— We breakfasted at Waterloo, 12. Miles from Baltimore, and at half past eleven in the morning alighted at my house in F. Street, Washington, where I found the part of my family who had remained here, all well— We very narrowly escaped oversetting on the way— On going to the Office I met Dr Thornton, with Major Moody, a British Officer— Found at the Office all the Clerks, excepting Mr Bailey, who is confined with a fever— Call at the President’s, and found Mr Calhoun with him. Mr Wirt came in while I was there— Some discussion concerning despatches received from R. Rush, with a confidential correspondence between G. Canning and him relating to South-America. Spoke also of H. Allen’s demand of an advance upon his Salary as Minister to Chili a question upon the Law of the last Session of Congress against advances— At my House, young Bourne of Baltimore came to renew his application for an appointment as Secretary of Legation, or as a Clerk in one of the Departments— I dined at Dr Thornton’s, with Major Moody and R. Forrest. After dinner Jeremy Robinson came with a long Story from Chili, against Captain Stewart, and Mr Prevost. A Mr Hitchcock came also for a Commission to F. W. Armstrong as Marshal for the District of Alabama, which he was extremely desirous of having made out and delivered to him to-morrow Morning— As he goes by the Steam-boat, and a day afterwards it would be too late for the sitting of the U.S. District Court in Alabama.
